===Goryeo (Koryŏ) Dynasty (918-1392) architecture=== [[File:Goryeo Seopum.jpg|190px|thumb|right|A Goryeo painting depicting a royal palace.]] Goryeo (Koryo) architecture is defined as the period between the 10th century and the 14th century. Much of the architecture in this period was related to religion and influenced by political power/ kingdom. Many buildings such as magnificent [[Buddhist temple]]s and [[pagodas]] were developed based on religious needs, as [[Buddhism]] played an important role in the culture and society at the time. It is unfortunate that little has survived to the present day, since most of the architecture from this period was built of wood. Also, the capital of the [[Goryeo]] dynasty was based in Gaesong, a city in modern-day North Korea. Its location has made it difficult for many historians in South Korea to study and analyze the architecture of this era.
Few remaining wooden structures from the late Goryeo period in [[South Korea]] show us significantly simpler bracketing than those from the 'Choson' period architecture. Bright and soft coloring of these structures had been further developed since the [[Three Kingdoms of Korea|Three Kingdoms]] era.<ref>[http://www.koreanculture.org/06about_korea/symbols/14dancheong.htm Dancheong<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622234947/http://www.koreanculture.org/06about_korea/symbols/14dancheong.htm |date=2008-06-22 }}</ref>

===Joseon Dynasty (1392-1910) architecture=== *{{commonscat inline|Architecture of the Joseon Dynasty}} *''See also: [[Joseon Dynasty#Architecture|Joseon Dynasty architecture]]; and [[Five Grand Palaces]].'' [[File:Donggwol-do.jpg|right|thumb|500px|''[[Donggwoldo]]'', a landscape of the once extensive grounds of [[Changdeokgung|Changdeokgung Palace]], a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and [[Changgyeonggung|Changgyeonggung Palace]]. Painted c. 1830.]]
Joseon architecture is defined as from the 14th century to the beginning of 20th century. The founding of the [[Joseon Dynasty]] in 1392 brought to power like-minded men steeped in the doctrines of [[Neo-Confucianism]], which had slowly percolated into Korea from China in the 14th century. This ushered in a new environment that was relatively hostile to Buddhism, causing the state to gradually shift its patronage from Buddhist temples to Confucian institutions. Throughout the early dynasty, the impetus to reform society along Neo-Confucian lines led to the construction of [[hyanggyo]] (local schools) in Seoul and numerous provincial cities. Here, sons of the aristocracy prepared for civil service careers in an atmosphere of Confucian learning. Although these institutions endured through the end of the dynasty, they began to fall out of favor in the mid-16th century for a variety of reasons. Among these, the rise in population made it the prospects of a civil service career less likely than in earlier years. Also, as the [[yangban]] aristocracy matured in its understanding of Neo-Confucianism, they grew more selective in the quality and type of instruction they favored for their sons. As a result, private Confucian academies ([[seowon]]) gradually supplanted hyanggyos and became a staple of rural aristocratic life until the end of the dynasty.
Neo-Confucianism inspired new architectural paradigms. Jaesil, or clan memorial halls, became common in many villages where [[Extended family|extended families]] erected facilities for common veneration of a distant ancestor. Jongmyo, or memorial shrines, were established by the government to commemorate exceptional acts of filial piety or devotion. Even beyond these archetypes, the [[aesthetics]] of Neo-Confucianism, which favored practicality, frugality, and harmony with nature, forged a consistent architectural style throughout Korean society.
The most famous town walls are those of Seoul and Suwon. The capital's stone wall, constructed in 1396 and rebuilt in 1422, was sixteen kilometers long (only traces remain today) and had eight gates (including Namdaemun, the South Gate); Suwon's town wall, completed in 1796, was a model of construction methods in Asia at that time, as it benefited from Western influence and techniques.

===Colonial period architecture===
{{refimprove section|date=April 2012}} {{Clear}} During the Japanese occupation in the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Colonial Korea]] era from 1910 to 1945, there was an attempt by the colonial government of the [[Empire of Japan]] to replace Korean architecture with [[Japanese architecture|Japanese architectural traditions]].<ref>Peter Bartholomew, 'Choson Dynasty Royal Compounds: Windows to a Lost Culture', in Transactions: Royal Asiatic Society, Korea Branch Vol. 68 (Seoul: RAS, 1993)</ref> Significant structures of Korean Imperial palace compounds and their traditional [[Korean gardens]] were demolished. Important landscape elements were removed and sold or taken for use in Japan. Ancient [[bunjae]] trees were taken for replanting as [[bonsai]] in Japanese gardens. Also during Japanese occupation, the construction of traditional Korean religious buildings (Buddhist or Confucian) was discouraged, as well as adaptations in Christian churches. Some Korean people resisted the Japanese nationalist agenda by building traditional Korean [[hanok]] homes, such as the houses of [[Jeonju]] village.<ref>[http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2881118 Hanok hotels become a hip choice]</ref> The colonial disregard for Korean architecture and its history left important Korean landmarks neglected and unmaintained, and the deterioration or demolition of significant examples of architecture resulted. Some historic buildings were also redecorated using Japanese ornamentation methods.
Japanese architecture was first introduced to Colonial Korea via transportation infrastructure-building programs. New [[railway]] lines had Japanese-type [[railway station]]s and [[hotel]]s. The Japanese also built new [[city hall]]s, post offices, [[barracks]] and [[military base]]s, jails and [[prison]]s, and [[police station]]s and [[Koban (police box)|police boxes (''koban'')]]. Having prohibited the use of the [[Korean language]] in the media and education, Japan built new schools for the Japanese education of Koreans.
Western 'Euro-American' Revival architectural styles were used for some new buildings important to the Japanese occupation in Korea. An example is the [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical style]] [[Japanese General Government Building, Seoul|Japanese General Government Building]] (1926), the [[Seoul Station#Old Seoul Station|Seoul Station]] (1925), and the [[Seoul City Hall]] (1926).
Materials for building construction in Korea were in short supply. The Korean [[Old growth forest|old-growth]] forests and particularly large [[Cupressaceae|cypress]] logs were under Japanese [[logging]] operations and shipped to Japan, along with other exportable [[building material]]s.
The Japanese occupation blocked 20th century Western design movements, including [[Art Deco]] and [[Modernist architecture]], from reaching Colonial Korea. Korean architecture with 20th-century influences did not develop until after Korean independence in 1946.

==Modern architecture==
===Post-war period and Korean War architecture=== After the [[Surrender of Japan]] in 1945, American architecture assumed supremacy. Under [[Douglas MacArthur]], who set Korean domestic and political policy from the [[Supreme Command of the Allied Powers]] headquarters in [[Tokyo]]. Korean architecture by Koreans began once again in domestic areas, with extensive repair of the missionary churches being given priority funding. Essential repair to infrastructure followed, more patch-work than new projects, and block-built hospitals, schools, industries began simple construction under military supervision.
Seoul had survived much of [[World War II]] but during the [[Korean War]] (1950–1953), many buildings were destroyed, with the city changing command between [[North Korea]]n and [[South Korea]]n powers five times. [[Urban warfare|Street-to-street fighting]] and [[artillery]] barrages levelled much of the city, as well as the bridges over the [[Han River (Korea)|Han River]]. Important architectural sites were overrun and burnt by invading armies, [[looting]] was extensive, and the urban landscape suffered with little money for repairs.
With the armistice, and distinct architectural styles determined by foreign governments began a long period of development.
In the north, [[Stalinist architecture|Stalinist]] and absolutist, often [[brutalist architecture]], was championed. North Korean architects studied in [[Moscow]] or [[Satellite state|Soviet satellites]], and brought back socialist worker styles and huge celebratory people's architecture on a grand and massively impressive scale. [[Nomenklatura|Nomenclatura]] lived in [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]-style apartment blocks, farmers and rural workers lived in traditional houses as they always had; urbanization did not occur. Grand buildings and huge public squares were developed in [[Pyongyang]] as architectural showpieces. Formal processional landscapes accompanied these sites. Nearly all architecture was government sponsored, and maintained great homogeneity of function and style.
In the south, American models defined all new Korean buildings of any importance, with domestic architecture both civil and rural keeping to traditional buildings, building techniques, and using local materials, and local vernacular styles. The pragmatic need to rebuild a country devastated by genocide, then a civil war, led to ad hoc buildings with no particular styles, extended repeatedly, and a factory system of simple cheap expendable buildings. As few Korean cities had a grid-system, and were often given limits by mountains, few if any urban landscapes had a sense of distinction; by the mid-1950s, rural areas were underfunded, urban areas overfilled, and [[urban sprawl]] began with little money to build distinctive important buildings.
Buildings tended to be built quickly with little regard for local identity. As the need for housing for workers increased, traditional [[hanok]] villages were razed, hundreds of simple cheap apartments were put up very fast, and [[Bedroom community|bedroom communities]] on the periphery of the urban centres grew, built and financed as company housing.
===Sports architecture===
South Korea was selected to host the [[1986 Asian Games]] and the [[1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Olympic games]], which spurred waves of new building activity. To market the country globally, international architects were encouraged to submit designs, introducing alternative concepts for modern architecture that began to put style and form ahead of spartan practicality. Historically, sports architecture has occupied the most money and the greatest expression of form identity within Korea. Hundreds of billions of [[South Korean won|won]] have been spent on defining Korea as a sports mecca with the architecture leading the way.
Most of the largest projects in the South, as in the North, were government sponsored works: but instead worked in confined, rather than open spaces, and worked with huge amounts of enclosed space, primarily in the state subsidized hugely expensive sports architecture. Korea since the 1990s had its most notable architectural works driven by sports: the two times which the country has hosted the Asian Games (1986 and 2014),the [[1988 Summer Olympics]],the [[2018 Winter Olympics]] [[2003 Summer Universiade]] and [[2015 Summer Universiade]], The country also hosted the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], as well as great support being given by the [[chaebol]]s such as the [[Samsung]] Group which itself owned the sports teams for marketing purposes.
Important architects at this time and their works, often led by the atelier-style architectural co-operative [[Space Group of Korea]], were:
* [[Park Kil-ryong]] * [[Jungup Kim or Kim Chung-up]] - Trained in France and designed the Olympic Memorial Gate/World Peace Gate, 1988. * [[Jongseong Kim]] – Weight Lifting Gymnasium, Olympic Park, 1986. * [[Kim Swoo Geun]] who trained in Tokyo - Olympic Stadium. 1984. Its total area is 133,649 square metres, with 100,000 seats. It is 245×180 m diameter and 830 m in perimeter. * [[Kyu Sung Woo]] – Olympic Village, 1984.
===Post-modern Korean architecture===
[[File:Hdipark.jpg|thumb|left|220px|[[Hyundai]] I-Park Tower.]] [[File:Jongno Tower.JPG|thumb|right|220px|[[Jongno Tower]].]]
It wasn't until the late 1980s and early 1990s that an entirely new generation of Korean architects had the freedom and the financing to build Korean architecture in a distinct Korean manner. This was a result of architects studying and training in Europe, Canada, and even in South America, and seeing the need for more of a sense of unique style, and more sophisticated materials. There was a new determination that nationalistic architectural elements had to be revived and refined. Buildings had to mean something within their cultural context.
Post-modern Korean architecture is defined as from 1986 to 2005. Cultural and museum buildings have followed; with city halls and buildings for the civil service appearing generally in a New York/Chicago style rather than following London or Paris trends.
Individuality and experimentation became the new cause for young architects, however the country as a whole was slow to move from the old traditions into seeing good architecture aesthetics as being important to the sense of a village, town, or city. Change was forced at times against intense resistance, and new buildings evolved at great cost to the architects and builders and within a great tension.
Much of the growth of new architecture came from retail stores, clothing shops, bistros, cafes, and bars; and the underside of architectural commissions, rather than from major [[government contracts]] or the financial and corporate community. Foreign corporations setting up Korean headquarters also brought in an entirely new spirit of architecture to define their own visions.
In recent years a number of large and iconic modernist projects have been developed in Seoul such as the 2008 [[Dominique Perrault]] building at [[Ewha Womans University]], the 2012 [[Seoul City Hall]] extension by [[iArc]] and the large [[Dongdaemun Design Plaza]] designed by [[Zaha Hadid]] and opened in 2014.
Important architects at this time include: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Architectural entity !Work |- |[[Um Tok-mun]] |[[Sejong Center|Sejong Cultural Centre]] |- |[[Kim Seok-Chul]] |[[Seoul Arts Centre]] |- | Korean Architects Collaborative International under the guidance of Fentress Architects |[[Incheon International Airport]] |}

{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=April 2018}} {{essay|date=April 2018}} {{Orphan|date=May 2018}} }}
'''Left-right asymmetry''' (LR asymmetry) refers to differences in structure ([[Symmetry in biology|symmetry]] breaking) across the mediolateral (left and right) plane in animals. This plane is defined with respect to the [[Anatomical terms of location|anteroposterior]] and [[Anatomical terms of location|dorsoventral]] axes and is perpendicular to both. Because the left-right plane is not strictly an axis (as it is not established through a [[morphogen]] gradient), to create asymmetry, the left and right sides need to be patterned separately.<ref>Palmer, A. R. (2004). Symmetry breaking and the evolution of development. ''Science'', ''306''(5697), 828-833</ref>
LR asymmetry is pervasive throughout [[Animal|metazoans]] and present throughout every major lineage. Notable examples include the large and small claws of the [[fiddler crab]], the left offset of the vertebrate heart, asymmetrical gut coiling in ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]],'' and dextral (clockwise) and sinistral (counterclockwise) coiling of [[Gastropoda|gastropods]]. This asymmetry can be restricted to a specific organ or feature, as in the crab claws, or be expressed throughout the entire body as in snails.
== Developmental basis == Components of the [[Nodal signaling pathway]] have been implicated in left-right determination in a diverse set of taxa.<ref name=":0">Levin et al. (1995). A molecular pathway determining left-right asymmetry in chick embryogenesis. ''Cell'' 82, 803-814.</ref><ref name=":1">Coutelis, J. B., González‐Morales, N., Géminard, C., & Noselli, S. (2014). Diversity and convergence in the mechanisms establishing L/R asymmetry in metazoa. ''EMBO Reports'', e201438972.</ref> While the mechanisms to set up the left-right sides appear to differ markedly among groups of organisms, ''[[NODAL|Nodal]]'' is consistently deployed in most of the lineages that have been examined (except for [[ecdysozoa]]ns).<ref name=":1" /> In established model organisms such as mouse, chick, ''D. melanogaster,'' and ''[[African clawed frog|Xenopus]],'' ongoing research has begun to focus on cellular level symmetry-breaking mechanisms (e.g. cytoskeletal chirality, ciliary flow) that may lead to differential expression of molecules such as Nodal.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tee|first=Yee Han|last2=Shemesh|first2=Tom|last3=Thiagarajan|first3=Visalatchi|last4=Hariadi|first4=Rizal Fajar|last5=Anderson|first5=Karen L.|last6=Page|first6=Christopher|last7=Volkmann|first7=Niels|last8=Hanein|first8=Dorit|last9=Sivaramakrishnan|first9=Sivaraj|title=Cellular chirality arising from the self-organization of the actin cytoskeleton|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ncb3137|journal=Nature Cell Biology|volume=17|issue=4|pages=445–457|doi=10.1038/ncb3137}}</ref>
=== Vertebrates === ''Nodal'' was first described in the chick embryo, where genes ''activin receptor IIa, [[Sonic hedgehog]] (Shh),'' and ''chick nodal-related 1 (cNR-1)'' were found to be asymmetrically expressed across [[Primitive knot|Hensen’s node]] with ''cnR-1'' expressed on the left side.<ref name=":0" /> Misexpressing ''Shh'' or ''activin receptor IIa'' on the right side randomized heart asymmetry in the chick. This asymmetrical gene expression appears to be triggered by cell movements in the node.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gros|first=Jerome|last2=Feistel|first2=Kerstin|last3=Viebahn|first3=Christoph|last4=Blum|first4=Martin|last5=Tabin|first5=Clifford J.|date=2009-05-15|title=Cell Movements at Hensen’s Node Establish Left/Right Asymmetric Gene Expression in the Chick|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/324/5929/941|journal=Science|volume=324|issue=5929|pages=941–944|doi=10.1126/science.1172478|issn=0036-8075|pmc=2993078|pmid=19359542}}</ref>
In mouse, the left side is distinguished from the right through Nodal flow.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nonaka|first=Shigenori|last2=Tanaka|first2=Yosuke|last3=Okada|first3=Yasushi|last4=Takeda|first4=Sen|last5=Harada|first5=Akihiro|last6=Kanai|first6=Yoshimitsu|last7=Kido|first7=Mizuho|last8=Hirokawa|first8=Nobutaka|title=Randomization of Left–Right Asymmetry due to Loss of Nodal Cilia Generating Leftward Flow of Extraembryonic Fluid in Mice Lacking KIF3B Motor Protein|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0092-8674(00)81705-5|journal=Cell|volume=95|issue=6|pages=829–837|doi=10.1016/s0092-8674(00)81705-5}}</ref> Originally described from ''inversus viscerum (iv)'' and ''inversion of embryonic turning (inv)'' mouse mutants, which are characterized by a randomization of left-right phenotypes, Nodal flow refers to the movement of nodal cilia to create a leftward flow of extraembryonic fluid.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Okada|first=Yasushi|last2=Nonaka|first2=Shigenori|last3=Tanaka|first3=Yosuke|last4=Saijoh|first4=Yukio|last5=Hamada|first5=Hiroshi|last6=Hirokawa|first6=Nobutaka|date=1999-10-01|title=Abnormal Nodal Flow Precedes Situs Inversus in iv and inv mice|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1097276500801975|journal=Molecular Cell|volume=4|issue=4|pages=459–468|doi=10.1016/S1097-2765(00)80197-5}}</ref> Carried in this leftward movement is Nodal, a signaling peptide from the [[Transforming growth factor beta|TGF-β]] family necessary to pattern left-right determination.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brennan|first=Jane|last2=Norris|first2=Dominic P.|last3=Robertson|first3=Elizabeth J.|date=2002-09-15|title=Nodal activity in the node governs left-right asymmetry|url=http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/16/18/2339|journal=Genes & Development|volume=16|issue=18|pages=2339–2344|doi=10.1101/gad.1016202|issn=0890-9369|pmc=187443|pmid=12231623}}</ref> In the lateral plate mesoderm, Nodal then activates a positive feedback loop promoting its expression and its downstream effector ''[[PITX2|Pitx2]].'' To prevent expansion to the rightward portion of the embryo, Nodal activates ''Lefty1'' and ''Lefty2,'' which repress the Nodal signaling pathway by competing with Nodal binding sites.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meno|first=Chikara|last2=Shimono|first2=Akihiko|last3=Saijoh|first3=Yukio|last4=Yashiro|first4=Kenta|last5=Mochida|first5=Kyoko|last6=Ohishi|first6=Sachiko|last7=Noji|first7=Sumihare|last8=Kondoh|first8=Hisato|last9=Hamada|first9=Hiroshi|date=1998-08-07|title=lefty-1 Is Required for Left-Right Determination as a Regulator of lefty-2 and nodal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867400814725|journal=Cell|volume=94|issue=3|pages=287–297|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(00)81472-5}}</ref>
Because Nodal flow through ciliary movement is not present in all vertebrates (e.g. the chick), asymmetric gene expression must be established in another way. One such idea posits that [[ion channel]]s and pumps (H+/K+ ATPase) generate differences in voltage and pH across the mediolateral plane, thus providing gradients to orient signaling molecules.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levin|first=Michael|last2=Thorlin|first2=Thorleif|last3=Robinson|first3=Kenneth R.|last4=Nogi|first4=Taisaku|last5=Mercola|first5=Mark|date=2002-10-04|title=Asymmetries in H+/K+-ATPase and Cell Membrane Potentials Comprise a Very Early Step in Left-Right Patterning|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S009286740200939X|journal=Cell|volume=111|issue=1|pages=77–89|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(02)00939-X}}</ref>
=== Non-vertebrate deuterostomes === Recently, work has shown that the Nodal-Pitx2 pathway is present and functional in the non-vertebrate [[deuterostome]]s (tunicates, sea urchins).<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Shimeld|first=Sebastian M.|last2=Levin|first2=Michael|date=2006-06-01|title=Evidence for the regulation of left-right asymmetry in Ciona intestinalis by ion flux|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/dvdy.20792/abstract|journal=Developmental Dynamics|volume=235|issue=6|pages=1543–1553|doi=10.1002/dvdy.20792|issn=1097-0177}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Molina|first=M Dolores|last2=de Crozé|first2=Noémie|last3=Haillot|first3=Emmanuel|last4=Lepage|first4=Thierry|date=2013-08-01|title=Nodal: master and commander of the dorsal–ventral and left–right axes in the sea urchin embryo|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959437X13000646|journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development|series=Developmental mechanisms, patterning and evolution|volume=23|issue=4|pages=445–453|doi=10.1016/j.gde.2013.04.010}}</ref> In tunicate ([[Ascidiacea|ascidian]]) ''[[Ciona intestinalis]]'' and ''[[Sea pineapple|Halocynthia roretzi]]'', ''Nodal'' is expressed on the left side of the developing embryo and leads to downstream expression of ''Pitx2.'' At earlier stages, similar H+/K+ ATPase ion channels are reported to be necessary for correct left-right patterning.<ref name=":2" /> While the role of cilia here is still unclear, one study observes that large-scale embryonic movements are required for left-right determination in ''H. roretzi,'' and that this movement is possibly achieved through ciliary movements.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nishide|first=Kazuhiko|last2=Mugitani|first2=Michio|last3=Kumano|first3=Gaku|last4=Nishida|first4=Hiroki|date=2012-04-15|title=Neurula rotation determines left-right asymmetry in ascidian tadpole larvae|url=http://dev.biologists.org/content/139/8/1467|journal=Development|volume=139|issue=8|pages=1467–1475|doi=10.1242/dev.076083|issn=0950-1991|pmid=22399684}}</ref>
In the sea urchin, ''Nodal'' is expressed on the right side of the embryo, in contrast to the tunicate and vertebrate condition on the left side.<ref name=":3" /> Because [[protostome]]s appear to also express ''Nodal'' on their right side instead of the left (discussed below), some have suggested that this lends further evidence for the dorsoventral [[Inversion (evolutionary biology)|inversion]] hypothesis.<ref name=":1" />
=== Protostomes ===
==== Ecdysozoa ==== While ''D. melanogaster'' and nematode ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' do show left-right asymmetry, the Nodal signaling pathway itself is absent in Ecdysozoa.<ref name=":1" /> Instead, cytoskeletal regulators such as Myo31DF, a type ID unconventional myosin, have been found to control left-right asymmetry in organ systems such as genitalia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spéder|first=Pauline|last2=Ádám|first2=Géza|last3=Noselli|first3=Stéphane|date=2006-04-06|title=Type ID unconventional myosin controls left–right asymmetry in Drosophila|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v440/n7085/full/nature04623.html|journal=Nature|volume=440|issue=7085|pages=803–807|doi=10.1038/nature04623|issn=0028-0836}}</ref>
==== Lophotrochozoa ==== Unlike in Ecdysozoa, the Nodal-Pitx2 pathways have been identified in many lineages within the [[Lophotrochozoa]]ns.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Martín-Durán|first=José M.|last2=Vellutini|first2=Bruno C.|last3=Hejnol|first3=Andreas|date=2016-12-19|title=Embryonic chirality and the evolution of spiralian left–right asymmetries|url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/371/1710/20150411|journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B|volume=371|issue=1710|pages=20150411|doi=10.1098/rstb.2015.0411|issn=0962-8436|pmid=27821523|pmc=5104510}}</ref> When found in [[brachiopod]]s and molluscs, these genes are asymmetrically expressed on the right.<ref name=":4" /> Platyhelminthes, annelids, and nermeteans lack a Nodal orthologue and instead only express Pitx2, which was expressed in association to the nervous system.<ref name=":4" />
== Whole body left-right asymmetry in gastropods == Whole body inversion is observed as chiral (dextral, sinistral) coiling in gastropods. While dextral coiling is the most common as it appears in 90-99% of living species, sinistral species still have arisen many times.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Asami|first=Takahiro|last2=Cowie|first2=Robert H.|last3=Ohbayashi|first3=Kako|date=1998-01-01|title=Evolution of Mirror Images by Sexually Asymmetric Mating Behavior in Hermaphroditic Snails|jstor=10.1086/286163|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=152|issue=2|pages=225–236|doi=10.1086/286163}}</ref>
=== Developmental basis of shell coiling === Gastropods undergo [[Cleavage (embryo)|spiral cleavage]], a feature commonly seen in lophotrochozoans. As the embryo divides, quartets of cells are oriented at angles to each other. In the snail ''Lymnaea stagnalis'', the direction of rotation during the first cell division signals whether the adult will show dextral or sinistral coiling,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Meshcheryakov|first=V. N.|last2=Beloussov|first2=L. V.|title=Asymmetrical rotations of blastomeres in early cleavage of gastropoda|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00848080|journal=Wilhelm Roux's archives of developmental biology|volume=177|issue=3|pages=193–203|doi=10.1007/BF00848080|issn=0340-0794}}</ref> At the third cleavage (8-cell stage), spindles in dextral snails are inclined clockwise whereas they are counterclockwise in sinistral snails.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Shibazaki|first=Yuichiro|last2=Shimizu|first2=Miho|last3=Kuroda|first3=Reiko|date=2004-08-24|title=Body Handedness Is Directed by Genetically Determined Cytoskeletal Dynamics in the Early Embryo|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982204005640|journal=Current Biology|volume=14|issue=16|pages=1462–1467|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2004.08.018}}</ref> Furthermore, injecting ''L. peregra'' sinistral eggs with the cytoplasm of dextral eggs before the second polar body formation will reverse the polarity of the sinistral embryos.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Freeman|first=Gary|last2=Lundelius|first2=Judith W.|title=The developmental genetics of dextrality and sinistrality in the gastropodLymnaea peregra|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00848443|journal=Wilhelm Roux's archives of developmental biology|volume=191|issue=2|pages=69–83|doi=10.1007/BF00848443|issn=0340-0794}}</ref> These data show that chirality is heritable and maternally deposited in ''Lymnaea''.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />
Several studies have begun to investigate the molecular basis of this inheritance. ''Nodal'' and ''Pitx2'' are expressed on different sides of the ''L. stagnalis'' embryo depending on its chirality – right for dextral, left for sinistral.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grande|first=Cristina|last2=Patel|first2=Nipam H.|date=2009-02-19|title=Nodal signalling is involved in left–right asymmetry in snails|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v457/n7232/full/nature07603.html|journal=Nature|volume=457|issue=7232|pages=1007–1011|doi=10.1038/nature07603|issn=0028-0836|pmc=2661027|pmid=19098895}}</ref> Downstream of ''Nodal, decapentaplegic (dpp),'' shows the same expression pattern.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Shimizu|first=Keisuke|last2=Iijima|first2=Minoru|last3=Setiamarga|first3=Davin HE|last4=Sarashina|first4=Isao|last5=Kudoh|first5=Tetsuhiro|last6=Asami|first6=Takahiro|last7=Gittenberger|first7=Edi|last8=Endo|first8=Kazuyoshi|date=2013-01-01|title=Left-right asymmetric expression of dpp in the mantle of gastropods correlates with asymmetric shell coiling|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/2041-9139-4-15|journal=EvoDevo|volume=4|pages=15|doi=10.1186/2041-9139-4-15|issn=2041-9139|pmc=3680195|pmid=23711320}}</ref> In limpets (gastropods without coiled shells) ''dpp'' is expressed symmetrically in ''Patella vulgata'' and ''Nipponacmea fuscoviridis''.<ref name=":8" /> Additionally, in ''N. fuscoviridis'', ''dpp'' has been shown to drive cell proliferation<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kurita|first=Yoshihisa|last2=Wada|first2=Hiroshi|date=2011-04-27|title=Evidence that gastropod torsion is driven by asymmetric cell proliferation activated by TGF-β signalling|url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2011/04/16/rsbl.2011.0263|journal=Biology Letters|pages=rsbl20110263|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2011.0263|issn=1744-9561|pmc=3169068|pmid=21525052}}</ref>
Upstream of Nodal, ''Lsdia1/2'' have been implicated in controlling ''L. stagnalis'' chirality.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Davison|first=Angus|last2=McDowell|first2=Gary S.|last3=Holden|first3=Jennifer M.|last4=Johnson|first4=Harriet F.|last5=Koutsovoulos|first5=Georgios D.|last6=Liu|first6=M. Maureen|last7=Hulpiau|first7=Paco|last8=Roy|first8=Frans Van|last9=Wade|first9=Christopher M.|title=Formin Is Associated with Left-Right Asymmetry in the Pond Snail and the Frog|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2015.12.071|journal=Current Biology|volume=26|issue=5|pages=654–660|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2015.12.071|pmc=4791482|pmid=26923788}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Kuroda|first=Reiko|last2=Fujikura|first2=Kohei|last3=Abe|first3=Masanori|last4=Hosoiri|first4=Yuji|last5=Asakawa|first5=Shuichi|last6=Shimizu|first6=Miho|last7=Umeda|first7=Shin|last8=Ichikawa|first8=Futaba|last9=Takahashi|first9=Hiromi|date=2016-10-06|title=Diaphanous gene mutation affects spiral cleavage and chirality in snails|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=6|doi=10.1038/srep34809|issn=2045-2322|pmc=5052593|pmid=27708420}}</ref> Davison et al. (2016) mapped the “chirality locus” to a 0.4 Mb region and determined that ''Lsdia2'' is the likely candidate for determining dextral or sinistral coiling.<ref name=":9" /> This is a diaphanous-related formin gene involved in cytoskeleton formation.<ref name=":9" /> Dextral embryos treated with drugs that inhibited formin activity phenocopied the sinistral condition. Concurrent work from Kuroda et al. (2016) identified the same ''Lsdia2'' gene (called ''Lsdia1'' in their study) but failed to reproduce the formin inhibition results in the Davison et al. study.<ref name=":10" /> Additionally, Kuroda et al. (2016) did not find asymmetrically expressed ''Lsdia2'' as was seen in the Davison et al. (2016) study.

'''Medium specificity''' is a consideration in [[aesthetics]] and [[art criticism]]. It is most closely associated with [[modernism]], but it predates it.<ref>http://csmt.uchicago.edu/glossary2004/specificity.htm</ref>
==Overview== According to [[Clement Greenberg]], who helped popularize the term, medium specificity holds that "the unique and proper area of competence" for a form of art corresponds with the ability of an artist to manipulate those features that are "unique to the nature" of a particular medium.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sharecom.ca/greenberg/modernism.html | title = Modernist Painting | author = Clement Greenberg |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060105194921/http://www.sharecom.ca/greenberg/modernism.html |archivedate = 2006-01-05}}</ref> For example, in painting, literal flatness and [[Abstract art|abstraction]] are emphasised rather than illusionism and [[figurative art|figuration]].<ref>Vanessa R. Schwartz, Jeannene M. Przyblyski, ''The Nineteenth-Century Visual Culture Reader'', Routledge, 2004, p8. {{ISBN|0-415-30866-6}}</ref>
Medium specific can be seen to mean that ''"the artwork is constituted by the characteristic qualities of the raw material."'' This would probably include the techniques used to manipulate the materials. ''"Medium-specificity is based on the distinct materiality of artistic media."'' As early as 1776 [[Gotthold Ephraim Lessing]] ''"contends that an artwork, in order to be successful, needs to adhere to the specific stylistic properties of its own medium."''<ref>http://csmt.uchicago.edu/glossary2004/specificity.htm</ref>
Today, the term is used both to describe artistic practices and as a way to analyze [[Visual arts|artwork]]. Critic [[N. Katherine Hayles]], for example, speaks of "media specific analysis."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.altx.com/EBR/riposte/rip12/rip12hay.htm | title = What Cybertext Theory Can't Do | author = N. Katherine Hayles |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060313112924/http://www.altx.com/EBR/riposte/rip12/rip12hay.htm |archivedate = 2006-03-13}}</ref> As discussed by critic Marshall Soules, medium specificity and media specific analysis are playing an important role in the emergence of [[new media]] art forms, such as [[Internet art]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mala.bc.ca/~soules/animate.htm | title = Animating the Language Machine: Computers and Performance | author = Marshall Soules |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060224032144/http://www.mala.bc.ca/~soules/animate.htm |archivedate = 2006-02-24}}</ref> Medium specificity suggests that a work of art can be said to be successful if it fulfills the promise contained in the medium used to bring the artwork into existence. Much debate can remain as to what a given medium best lends itself to.
Art dialogue in the post-modern period has tended to steer away from medium specificity as a particularly relevant principle.<ref>http://csmt.uchicago.edu/glossary2004/specificity.htm Medium Specificity</ref>
== See also == *[[Classificatory disputes about art]] *[[Form follows function]] *[[Ornament and Crime]] *[[Truth to materials]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070208085350/http://chicagoschoolmediatheory.net/glossary2004/specificity.htm Medium Specificity] * [http://csmt.uchicago.edu/glossary2004/specificity.htm University of Chicago: Theories of Media: Glossary: medium specificity]

The '''Native American Renaissance''' is a term originally coined by [[literary critic|critic]] Kenneth Lincoln in the 1983 book ''Native American Renaissance'' to categorise the significant increase in production of [[Literature|literary works]] by [[Native Americans in the United States]] in the late 1960s and onwards. A. Robert Lee and Alan Velie note that the book's title "quickly gained currency as a term to describe the efflorescence on literary works that followed the publication of [[N. Scott Momaday]]'s ''[[House Made of Dawn]]'' in 1968".<ref>Lee and Velie, "Introduction", in ''Native American Renaissance: Literary Imagination and Achievement'', p. 3</ref> Momaday's novel garnered critical acclaim, including the [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] in 1969.
==Earlier works by Native American authors== Prior to the publication of ''House Made of Dawn,'' few Native American authors had published works of fiction that reached wide readership. Writers such as [[William Apess]], [[John Rollin Ridge]] and [[Simon Pokagon]] published works to little fanfare in the nineteenth century. Prior to the onset of [[World War II|WWII]], [[Mourning Dove (author)|Mourning Dove]], [[John Milton Oskison]], [[John Joseph Mathews]], [[Zitkala-Sa]], [[Charles Eastman]] and [[D'Arcy McNickle]] published literary works, although these works were relatively few in number.
==The Renaissance==
===Literary Renaissance===
In the work ''Native American Literatures: An Introduction,'' author Suzanne Lundquist suggests the Native American Renaissance has three elements:
*Reclamation of heritage through literary expression; *Discovery and reevaluation of early texts by Native American authors; and *Renewed interest in customary tribal artistic expression (i.e. mythology, ceremonialism, ritual, and the oral tradition of narrative transmission).<ref>Lundquist, Suzanne Evertsen. ''Native American Literatures: An Introduction.'' Consortium International Publishing Group: New York, NY. 2004, p. 38</ref>
Lincoln points out that in the late 1960s and early 1970s, a generation of Native Americans were coming of age who were the first of their respective tribal communities to receive a substantial English-language education, particularly outside [[Indian boarding school]]s, and with more graduating from colleges and universities. Conditions for [[Indigenous peoples|Native people]], while still very harsh during this period, had moved beyond the survival conditions of the early half of the century.
A period of [[historical revisionism]] was underway, as historians were more willing to look at difficulties in the history of the invasion and colonization of the [[North America|North American continent]]. As they explored the colonial and "[[Wild West]]" eras, some historians were more careful to represent events from the Native American perspective. This work inspired [[public interest]] in Native cultures and within Native American communities themselves; it was also a period of activism within Native American communities to achieve greater sovereignty and civil rights.
The ferment also inspired a group of young Native American writers, who emerged in the fields of poetry and novel-writing. In the span of a few years, these writers worked to expand the Native American literary [[Western canon|canon]].
By the 1980s, the rapid increase in materials and the development of [[Native American Studies]] departments and programs at several universities, such as [[the University of California, Los Angeles]]; [[Dartmouth College]], and [[Eastern Washington University]], led to the founding of scholarly journals, such as ''SAIL (Studies in American Indian Literature)'' and ''[[Wicazo Sa Review|Wíčazo Ša Review]]'' (1985). With the heightened interest in Native American writing, publishers established specialized imprints, such as [[HarperCollins|Harper and Row]]'s Native American Publishing Programme, which had the goal of promoting new voices and publication opportunities.
===Other meanings=== Although the primary use of the term has been literary, it has been used in a wider sense to describe "an increasing prosperity and sense of achievement among Indians [...] a widespread economic and cultural rebirth."<ref>Lee and Velie, p. 3</ref> For example, Joan Nagel applies the term to the totality of "the resurgence of American Indian ethnic identification and the renascence of tribal cultures during the 1970s and 1980s."<ref>Joane Nagel, "False Faces: Ethnic Identity, Authenticity and Fraud in Native American Discourse and Politics," in ''Identity and Social Change'', ed. Joseph E. Davis (New Brunswick: Transaction, 2000), p. 85</ref>
==Native American Renaissance writers==
Writers typically included in the ''Native American Renaissance'' include:
*[[N. Scott Momaday]] ([[Kiowa]]), ''[[House Made of Dawn]]'' (1968) *[[Duane Niatum]] ([[Klallam]]), ''Ascending Red Cedar Moon'' (1974) *[[Leslie Marmon Silko]] ([[Laguna Pueblo|Laguna]]), [[Ceremony (Silko novel)|''Ceremony'']] (1977) *[[Gerald Vizenor]] ([[White Earth Chippewa|Chippewa]]), ''Darkness in Saint Louis Bearheart'' (1978) *[[James Welch (poet)|James Welch]] ([[Piegan Blackfeet|Blackfeet]] and [[A'aninin]]), ''[[Winter in the Blood]]'' (1974) *[[Joy Harjo]] ([[Muscogee]]), ''The Last Song'' (1975) *[[Wikipedia talk:Articles for creation/Barney Bush - Native American Author (Shawnee)|Barney Bush]], ''Petroglyphs'' (1981) *[[Simon J. Ortiz]] ([[Acoma Pueblo|Acoma]]), ''From Sand Creek: Rising In This Heart Which Is Our America'' (1981) *[[Louise Erdrich]] ([[Ojibwe|Chippewa]]), ''[[Love Medicine]]'' (1984) *[[Paula Gunn Allen]] (Laguna), ''The Woman Who Owned the Shadows'' (1984) *[[Maurice Kenny]] ([[Mohawk people|Mohawk]]), ''Tekonwatonti/Molly Brant (1735-1795): Poems of War'' (1992) *[[nila northSun]] ([[Shoshone]]), ''A snake in her mouth: poems 1974-96'' (1997)
John Gamber argues that the characteristics of Renaissance writers are as follows: devotion to a sacred landscape; a homing-in plot, often associated with a protagonist's return to the reservation; the treatment of a mixed-blood protagonist's dilemma between two worlds as a central theme.<ref>"'We've Been Stuck in Place since ''House Made of Dawn'':Sherman Alexie and the Native American Renaissance", in Lee and Velie, p. 189.</ref> Erika Wurth points out that writers of this period were often concerned with writing for a non-Native audience.<ref>Erika Wurth, "The Fourth Wave", http://waxwingmag.org/writing.php?item=344</ref> Wurth and Gamber both agree that a new phase in Native writing began with the works of writers such as [[Sherman Alexie]], who rejected many of the formal and thematic concerns of Renaissance-era writing.
==Criticism==
The term ''Native American Renaissance'' has been criticized on a number of points. As James Ruppert writes, "Scholars hesitate to use the phrase because it might imply that Native writers were not producing significant work before that time, or that these writers sprang up without longstanding community and tribal roots. Indeed, if this was a rebirth, what was the original birth?"<ref>James Ruppert, "Fiction: 1968–Present". In ''The Cambridge Companion to Native American Literature'', ed. Kenneth M. Roemer and Joy Porter (CUP, 2005). Page 173 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I3_cSqmbXd8C&pg=PA173&lpg=PA173&dq=%22native+american+renaissance%22&source=bl&ots=iBTW6Icptc&sig=EKr6NFqSyQlqPl1ypMYE2w9tRrE&hl=en&ei=ej43Sq6TCYuQsAa2-8GwCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#PPP1,M1]</ref> Other critics have described it as "a source of controversy,<ref>Craig Womack, "Book-Length Native Literary Criticism", in ''Reasoning Together'' by Janice Acoose, Lisa Brooks, Craig S. Womack, Tol Foster, Daniel Heath Justice, Christopher B Teuton (Oklahoma, 2008), page 15 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Zj79HmexugcC&pg=PA200&dq=%22native+american+renaissance%22&lr=#PPA14,M1]</ref>". Rebecca Tillett argues that "While the definition of the recent burgeoning of Native writing as a "renaissance" is highly accurate in its description of the sudden growth in the numbers of Native writers finding publication, it is also profoundly inaccurate in its tendence to obscure the often specifically political histories of Indian oratory and writings upon which many Native writers are drawing."<ref>Rebecca Tillett, "On the Cutting Edge," in ''Native American Renaissance: Literary Imagination and Achievement'', p. 85</ref>

''Native American Literatures: An Introduction.'' '''The New York Women Composers, Inc.''' (NYWC) is a professional organization for women composers. The organization is meant to create opportunities for performing, recording, networking and mentoring for its members and aims to benefit all women composers.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f-b3yWUQ3X4|title=Minding Your Business 04/17/12 - New York Women Composers Part 1|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> The organization also works for the full inclusion of women composers' work into concert repertoire.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.newyorkwomencomposers.org/resources/cv24mar2013_program.pdf|title=Composers Voice Presents: New York Women Composers|date=2013|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref>
==History and activities== The association was founded by [[Elizabeth Bell (composer)|Elizabeth Bell]], Lucy Coolidge, [[Ann Callaway]] and Robert Friou in 1984.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gQcKAQAAMAAJ&q=%22New+York+Women+Composers,+Inc.%22&dq=%22New+York+Women+Composers,+Inc.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBGoVChMI84vxwozCyAIVgWw-Ch2LzgER|title=Women and music in America since 1900: an encyclopedia, Volume 2|author=Burns, Kristine Helen|publisher=Greenwood Press|date=2002|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> Membership is open to women composers of serious concert music who are residents of [[New York City]] and the greater [[New York City]] metropolitan area. It is also open to members of occupations that support the recognition of women as composers.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.newyorkwomencomposers.org|title=New York Women Composers, Inc.|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref> The New York Women Composers, Inc., is recognized as a resource for women seeking support for their compositions.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.acdacal.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/ECCO-Women-Composers-resource-list.pdf|title=The XX-Files: Great literature by women composers|date=2013|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://library.uoregon.edu/music/researchguides/womguide.html|title=WOMEN in MUSIC RESEARCH GUIDE: A Checklist for Research|date=2012|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref>
The organization produces premiere and performance events.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.internationalwomensday.com/esearch.asp?country=223&town=New+York+City#.Vh3F83qrTy0|title=Search International Women's Day Events by Country|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> It also produces media programs to increase recognition of women composers, such as ''Here and Now: An Explanation of the Creative Mind, 1988''.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FKDGY4U27QMC&pg=PA208&dq=new+york+women+composers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAWoVChMIt5iauffAyAIViRo-Ch1nvABJ#v=onepage&q=new%20york%20women%20composers&f=false|title=Women Composers: The Lost Tradition Found|first=Diane|last=Jezic|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Wood|date=1988|publisher=The Feminist Press|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> The group also publishes a catalog of music by women composers to allow easier access by musicians and directors seeking works for performance,<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p6miYGKhYpMC&pg=PA591&dq=new+York+women+composers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCWoVChMIusa0-PnAyAIViGs-Ch2vngOx#v=onepage&q=new%20York%20women%20composers&f=false|title=Chamber Music: A Research and Information Guide|author=Baron, John H.|date=2002|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HOTjukhDFYoC&pg=PA159&dq=new+York+women+composers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCDgKahUKEwjim5ug-8DIAhUBPT4KHb0uARk#v=onepage&q=new%20York%20women%20composers&f=false|title=Checklist of Writings on American Music, 1640-1992, Volumes 1-2|author=Barco, Guy A.|date=1996|publisher=Scarecrow Press|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> and presents awards for support of women's compositions.<ref>{{citation |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1957&dat=19940611&id=P2FGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KOkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1151,2482161&hl=en|publisher=The Daily Gazette|title=Composers' Award|date=11 June 1994|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
==Grants== The New York Women Composers, Inc., supports women composers in the state of New York by providing annual Seed Money Grant Program awards of $750 each for concerts or CD recording projects that support performance of music by NYWC members.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.music-usa.org/newyorkwomencomposers/news.php4?v=n&keepThis=true&TB_iframe=true|title=New York Women Composers, Inc., News|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

'''PVC clothing''', commonly known as "vinyl clothing", is shiny clothing made of the plastic [[polyvinyl chloride]] (PVC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/chebi/searchId.do?chebiId=53243 |title=poly(vinyl chloride) (CHEBI:53243) |publisher=Ebi.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> The PVC plastic is also called vinyl. For this reason, this type of clothing is also called vinyl clothing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthybuilding.net/pvc/SortingOutVinyls.html |title=Sorting Out The Vinyls – EVA, PEVA, PVA, PVB, & PVC |publisher=Healthybuilding.net |date=April 28, 2005 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> PVC is sometimes confused with the similarly shiny [[patent leather]].
The terms "PVC", "vinyl" and "PU" tend to be used interchangeably by retailers for clothing made from shiny plastic-coated fabrics. These fabrics usually consist of a backing woven from [[polyester]] fibers with a surface coating of shiny plastic. The plastic layer itself is typically a blend of PVC and [[polyurethane]] (PU), with 100% PVC producing a stiff fabric with a glossy shine and 100% PU producing a stretchy fabric with a silky shine. A manufacturer's label may say, for example, 67% polyester, 33% polyurethane for a fabric that contains no PVC; or 80% polyvinyl chloride, 20% polyurethane with mention of the polyester backing omitted.
The PVC can also be produced in bright colours (black, red, white, blue, orange, pink, silver, striped, etc.), adding further visual stimulus to the physical sensations produced by the material. The more frequently found colors are black and red. The PVC clothes are very associated with [[Retro-futurism|retro-futuristic look]], [[Goth subculture|Goth]], [[Punk rock|Punk]], [[alternative fashion]]s and [[clothing fetish]]. A common stereotype is the image of a [[dominatrix]] wearing a skin-tight PVC [[catsuit]], usually jet-black. In some cities it is more common to see people wearing PVC clothes, especially in large cities such as Berlin, London, New York City, Montreal, San Francisco, etc.
==History==
The plastics were used in clothing since its invention, particularly in raincoats. But PVC clothing became more noted in the 1960s and early 1970s fashion trend.<ref>Fashion From Ancient Egypt to the Present Day, by Mila Contini, p. 317</ref> The fashion designers of that era saw the PVC plastic as the ideal material to design futuristic clothes. During that era, boots, raincoats, dresses and other PVC garments were made in many colors and even transparent and worn in public areas to some degrees. At that time it was also common to see PVC clothes on films and TV series such as [[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]], for example. And since then these shiny [[Plastic clothing|plastic clothes]] became a [[PVC fetishism|fetish]] object.
In mid 1990s, clothes made of PVC have been prevalent in young people's fashions, particularly in jackets, skirts and trousers, also appearing in the media.<ref name="modices">{{cite web |url=http://modices.com.br/moda/a-proxima-textura-vinil/ |title=A próxima textura: vinil |publisher=Modices |date=March 22, 2011 |accessdate=2013-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117100002/http://modices.com.br/moda/a-proxima-textura-vinil/ |archivedate=January 17, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://renataabala.wordpress.com/2012/06/01/trend-alert-pecas-de-vinil/ |title=Trend Alert…Peças de Vinil… | Renata Bala – Consultora de Moda |publisher=Renataabala.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> During the mid-1990s it was common to see presenters, models, actresses, actors, singers and other celebrities wearing PVC clothes on TV and magazines. As fashions come round and round again, it would seem that PVC are appearing again in mainstream street fashions as well as continuing to be central to the fetish scene.<ref name="modices" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.institutodopvc.org/pvcatualidades/noticia.php?edicao=36&mat=63&lang=pt |title=PVC Atualidades OnLine |publisher=Institutodopvc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820051647/http://www.institutodopvc.org/pvcatualidades/noticia.php?edicao=36&mat=63&lang=pt |archivedate=August 20, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Fashion designers such as [[Jean Paul Gaultier]], [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Pierre Cardin]] and [[André Courrèges]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://almanaque.folha.uol.com.br/courreges.htm |title=Courrèges |publisher=Almanaque.folha.uol.com.br |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portaisdamoda.com.br/noticiaInt~id~15774~n~andre+courreges+volta+ao+mundo+da+moda.htm |title=André Courrèges volta ao mundo da moda |publisher=Portaisdamoda.com.br |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> have used PVC in their collections. Since 2010, the PVC has been the target of fashion not only for the female public but also to the male public.

Rabanne]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Laverty |first=Chris |url=http://clothesonfilm.com/two-for-the-road-audrey-hepburn-outfits-part-one/1318/ |title=Two For the Road: Audrey Hepburn's outfits – Part One Bazooka Boom]] released a music video called [[Hooli Gun Yo]]. In this music video the singer girl appears wearing a red PVC dress.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yb6d8r2GF64 |title=Chernobyl feat. Bazooka Boom – Hooli-Gun-Yo |publisher=YouTube |date=September 13, 2010 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> *Also in 2010, the English newsreader and television presenter [[Mary Nightingale]] wore a black PVC catsuit in a charity show called [[Newsroom's Got Talent]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-7nbm7B0mk4 |title=ITV News perform Footloose at Newsroom's Got Talent 2010 |publisher=YouTube |date=September 21, 2010 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Rachel Quigley |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1312883/Mary-Nightingale-vamps-PVC-catsuit-Newsreaders-Got-Talent.html |title=Mary Nightingale vamps it up in PVC catsuit at Newsreaders' Got Talent |publisher=Mail Online |date=September 17, 2010 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> *In recent years, PVC clothing have appeared in the media, in movies such as ''[[The Matrix]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1310687/Matrix-star-Carrie-Anne-Moss-dresses-comfy-sweats.html |title=Matrix star Carrie Anne Moss dresses down in comfy sweats |publisher=Mail Online |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> in the television series, in singers such as [[Britney Spears]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yy5cKX4jBkQ |title=Britney Spears – Born To Make You Happy |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> [[Nicole Scherzinger]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bwzbIoKcXnE&list=PLDBsfaFpF9812KAtiTtPYrX_SgFqcAYGY&index=165 |title=[pcdworld.co.uk] Nicole Scherzinger – Poison (BBC Radio 1's Big Weekend – 14th May 2011) |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> [[Jennifer Lopez]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xmap94TcDNs&list=PLDBsfaFpF9812KAtiTtPYrX_SgFqcAYGY&index=42 |title=Wisin & Yandel – Follow The Leader ft. Jennifer Lopez |publisher=YouTube |date=May 14, 2011 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> and [[Mýa]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dC8bycIYdF0 |title=Mya – Case of The Ex (LIVE TOTP) in black PVC pants |publisher=YouTube |date=November 18, 2012 |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref> or even in the fashion trends. *In 2017 game [[Splatoon 2]], one of the idols named Marina wears a PVC half jacket.
==Caring for PVC clothing==
PVC clothing requires some care to make it last longer and maintain its appearance. It is known that PVC clothes are made with a fabric covered with a plastic layer. For this reason, the PVC clothes should not be over-stretched, to avoid damage to the plastic layer. When excessively stretching the clothing, the plastic layer can lose its smooth texture and stay striated, losing also part of the original shine, and may even tear.
If the PVC clothing is not soiled, many people will just freshen the polyester inside up with a fabric refresher product and wipe the plastic outside with a damp sponge. If there is need, PVC clothes should be washed by hand with warm water and a small amount of liquid [[detergent]]. [[Laundry detergent|Washing powder]] should not be used because the flakes can remain on clothing after washing, and also can stick to the plastic layer.<ref name="wickedvegas">{{cite web|url=http://www.wickedvegas.net/vinylcare.html |title=Vinyl, PVC Taking Care of your Clothing |publisher=Wicked-Vegas |date= |accessdate=2013-02-26}}</ref>
To remove the detergent one should use cold water and after turning the garment inside out it should be left to dry under the shade. After drying the inside (polyester fabric), then it must be turned in the right direction to dry outside (plastic layer).<ref name="wickedvegas" />
PVC clothing should never be [[Clothes iron|ironed]]. This type of clothing is made of heat sensitive plastics and which may melt under the iron, and high temperatures should be avoided from any source, such as flames, [[clothes dryer|dryers]], and cigarettes. The fumes from burning or smoking PVC plastic are dangerous.<ref name="wickedvegas" />
Different coloured PVC garments, especially white, should be stored separately from each other, otherwise staining may occur. PVC clothing is best stored hanging in a garment bag away from other clothing.<ref name="wickedvegas" />
The fabric used for PVC clothes is typically plastic-coated polyester. This PVC fabric is more resistant to wear and tear than rubber, and PVC clothing does not require the use of any shining products. However one can polish PVC clothing if desired with liquid [[silicone]] spray which is available from car accessory shops.<ref name="wickedvegas" />

{{Infobox theatre group | name = Prospect Theatre Company | image = | imagesize = | caption = | formed = 1961 | disbanded = 1980 | genre = Classical | location = [[Cambridge]] and [[Edinburgh]] | members = | ArtisticDirector = [[Toby Robertson]] | notable = [[Ian McKellen]], [[Timothy West]] | homepage = <!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> }} '''The Prospect Theatre Company''' was an English company founded, as '''Prospect Productions''', in 1961. Based at the [[Cambridge Arts Theatre|Arts Theatre, Cambridge]] from 1964 until 1969, the company, with [[Toby Robertson]] as artistic director and [[Richard Cottrell]] as associate director, toured both nationally and internationally with a mainly classical repertoire, providing notable appearances of such actors as [[Ian McKellen]] and [[Timothy West]]. The company became closely associated with the [[Edinburgh Festival]] after its first appearance there in 1967. Separating from the Arts Theatre in 1969, the company, renamed The Prospect Theatre Company, survived without a permanent base for the next eight years under the direction of Toby Robertson, mounting productions in which [[Derek Jacobi]] and [[Dorothy Tutin]] made significant appearances. Eventually the company found a new home at London's [[Old Vic]] in 1977: two years later it became the Old Vic Theatre Company. Though noted for its exemplary ensemble playing, the company lost its [[Arts Council of Great Britain]] funding in 1980 after Timothy West's first season as Robertson's successor, leading to Prospect's demise.
==Early years, Cambridge and Edinburgh== [[Iain Mackintosh]], [[Richard Cottrell]] and [[Elizabeth Sweeting]] formed Prospect Productions in 1961 to present a summer season of plays at the [[Oxford Playhouse]]. A successful first season led to a further season in 1962. The following year, when the Playhouse closed for renovations, Prospect became a touring company associated with the [[Century Theatre (UK)|Century Theatre]]. [[Toby Robertson]] directed the last play of the season, [[Vanbrugh]]'s ''[[The Provoked Wife]]'', with [[Eileen Atkins]] and [[Trevor Martin]]. The production opened the newly restored [[Georgian Theatre Royal]] in [[Richmond, North Yorkshire]], then transferred to the [[Vaudeville Theatre]], London. The success of the Oxford seasons prompted the idea that Prospect should present productions beyond the summer season each year.<ref name= mckellenProspect>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title =Prospect Theatre Company | work = | publisher =Ian McKellen Stage | date = | url =http://www.mckellen.com/stage/r2/prospect.htm | doi = | accessdate = 4 September 2014 | archiveurl = | archivedate = }}</ref>
In 1964, with support from the [[Arts Council of Great Britain]] and [[Dadie Rylands|Dr. George Rylands]], Prospect became a touring company based at the [[Cambridge Arts Theatre|Arts Theatre, Cambridge]], with Toby Robertson as artistic director, Richard Cottrell as associate director, and Iain Mackintosh as administrator. Between 1964 and 1966 Prospect staged 15 productions, presenting well-known plays as well as several rarely performed Classics including Vanbrugh's ''The Confederacy'', with [[Robert Eddison]] and [[Hy Hazell]], to celebrate the third centenary of Vanbrugh's birth, and [[Etherege]]'s ''[[The Man of Mode]]'', and a number of new plays. [[Timothy West]] joined the Company in 1966 to play [[Prospero]]. Later that year Prospect had its first invitation to the [[Edinburgh Festival]].<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
Prospect's first Edinburgh Festival appearance in 1967 was with [[Chekhov]]'s ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'', [[Lila Kedrova]] playing Madam Ranyevskaya in Cottrell's production. The production transferred to London, where Kedrova won the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' Best Actress of the Year Award. 1968 saw the production of Prospect's first "musical" - Gay's ''[[Beggar's Opera]]'', which was also the first Prospect show to be televised, and in 1969 the Company appeared for the first time at the Assembly Hall.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
At the 1969 Edinburgh festival [[Ian McKellen]] made his breakthrough performances with the company as [[Richard II (play)|Richard II]] (directed by Cottrell) and Marlowe's [[Edward II (play)|Edward II]] (directed by Robertson), the latter in the play's first professional revival for 300 years and causing a storm of protest over the enactment of the homosexual Edward's lurid death.<ref name=Scotsman>{{cite web | url= http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/obituary-toby-robertson-obe-theatre-director-1-2400165| publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]'' | accessdate=2013-09-16 | date=6 September 2012 | title= Obituary: Toby Robertson, OBE, theatre director | first=Alasdair | last= Steven | work=The Scotsman }}</ref> Timothy West appeared as McKellen's sparring partner in both those productions,<ref name= mckellenProspect/> which subsequently toured Britain and Europe before being staged at the [[Mermaid Theatre]] in London and breaking box-office records at the [[Piccadilly Theatre]].<ref name=Guardian>{{cite web | url= https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/jul/08/toby-robertson | publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' | accessdate=2013-09-16 | date=8 July 2012 | title= Toby Robertson obituary| first=Michael | last=Coveney | work=}}</ref>
Between 1967 and 1977 Prospect was invited to appear at eight Edinburgh International Festivals, and largely as a result of its close association with the Edinburgh Festival, Prospect was asked to tour abroad for the British Council, visiting the Middle East, Russia, Hong Kong, and Australia.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
==Years of touring== In 1969 the Company was asked to extend its touring to the large "No 1" theatres in the regions; at the same time the Cambridge Arts Theatre wanted Prospect to help in the formation of a new theatre company. As these two developments pointed in totally different directions with implications of a conflicting scale of work, Richard Cottrell left Prospect to become director of the newly formed [[Cambridge Arts Theatre#Cambridge Theatre Company|Cambridge Theatre Company]]: Toby Robertson became cirector of Prospect, and its role as the UK's leading touring company was recognised, with its new name - The Prospect Theatre Company.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
Under Robertson, the company pioneered a style of production in which stage designs and setting were kept to a minimum, partly from the belief that Shakespeare's plays in particular benefited from an uncluttered approach; this style also suited the company's needs when touring regional theatres, for which flexibility of staging was essential.<ref name= mckellenProspect/><ref name=Guardian/> Emphasis was placed instead on quality acting and strikingly designed costumes, complemented by lighting and incidental music.<ref name= mckellenProspect/> [[Carl Davis]] composed several scores for the company, including for a modern dress production of ''[[Love's Labours Lost]]'' (1971), ''[[Pericles]]'' (1973), and ''Pilgrim's Progress'' (1974/5) which led directly to the musical ''War Music'' (1977) with words by [[Homer]] and [[Christopher Logue]] and music by Donald Fraser.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
From 1970 to 1976 four major productions were created each year. As the only major company touring nationally, the choice of repertoire tended to be drawn more from the classics at the expense of new work. But alongside several Shakespeare productions the company staged such plays as [[Thomas Otway]]'s ''[[Venice Preserv'd]]'', [[Charles Macklin]]'s ''The Man of the World'', [[Turgenev]]'s ''[[A Month in the Country (play)|A Month in the Country]]'' (with Derek Jacobi, Timothy West and Dorothy Tutin, who won two major acting awards for her performance), Chekhov's ''[[Ivanov (play)|Ivanov]]'', and [[Peter Shaffer]]'s ''[[Royal Hunt of the Sun]]''. A series of chamber works were commissioned, including Jane McCulloch's ''The Grand Tour'' for the Entry into Europe celebrations - an entertainment seen in London, Edinburgh, and the 1974 Brighton Festival.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
The strain of touring and meeting the increasingly high standards expected by theatre audiences throughout the country began to tell, and even with occasional London seasons either at the [[Roundhouse (venue)|Round House]] or in the West end, it was felt increasingly desirable that Prospect should once again have a permanent and preferably metropolitan base to sustain its regional work.<ref name= mckellenProspect/><ref name=rowell157>Rowell, p. 157</ref>
==Joining the Old Vic== [[Image:Waterloo the old vic 1.jpg|thumb|alt=The Old Vic, London.|The Old Vic Theatre, London]] Looking for a suitable London base, Robertson believed that the [[Old Vic]] would best meet the company's needs and would add lustre to its reputation. For two years he sustained a campaign for the Old Vic to make Prospect its resident company.<ref name=rowell157/> For the Old Vic, Robertson's overtures proved increasingly hard to resist in the face of poor box office returns achieved by productions staged by other companies at the theatre; against this, Prospect staged a highly successful season which opened in May 1977, including ''Hamlet'' with Derek Jacobi, ''[[Antony and Cleopatra]]'' with [[Alec McCowen]] and Dorothy Tutin; and ''[[Saint Joan (play)|Saint Joan]]'' with [[Eileen Atkins]].<ref name=rowell158>Rowell, p. 158</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title =History of the Old Vic, 1950-1999 | work = | publisher =The Old Vic | date = | url =http://www.oldvictheatre.com/about-us/history-of-the-old-vic-2/1950-1999/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 5 September 2014 | archiveurl = | archivedate = }}</ref> In July the Governors of The Old Vic announced "a marriage that was all but a merger" between the Vic and Prospect. In September Toby Robertson, director of Prospect, was asked to take artistic control of The Old Vic, and Christopher Richards, general manager of The Old Vic, became general manager of Prospect.<ref name= mckellenProspect/>
One major problem, though, was the terms of Prospect's funding by the Arts Council: this was on the basis of it being a touring company, and the Council - already funding the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] and the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] in London - could not accept a case for a third major company in the capital and repeatedly refused requests to fund any London seasons staged by Prospect. Therefore any London-based productions would have to succeed financially without Arts Council support. Prospect's first season at the Old Vic recouped its costs but left no surplus to fund future productions. Further stagings by visiting companies were box office failures and stretched the theatre's finances to breaking point.<ref>Rowell, p. 159</ref>
Yet Prospect continued to draw audiences to the Old Vic where other companies failed. The company played a five-month season from January to May 1978, adding ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' to their repertory, and a four-month season from September to December presenting ''[[The Rivals]]'', ''[[The Lady's Not for Burning]]'' with Atkins, and ''[[King Lear]]'' with [[Anthony Quayle]] in the title role.<ref>Rowell, pp. 159-60</ref> In December that year, the governors of the Old Vic agreed to a five-year contract with Prospect, announcing to the press on 23 April that henceforth they would be styled "Prospect Productions Ltd., trading as the Old Vic Company".<ref name=rowell160>Rowell, p. 160</ref> Unfortunately Prospect's touring commitments kept the company out of the theatre for the first half of 1979, leaving the theatre to sink further into debt. The company returned in July with Jacobi's ''Hamlet'' (toured afterwards to Denmark, Australia and China, the first English theatre company to tour that country),<ref name=Continuum/> followed by ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', and ''[[The Government Inspector]]'' with [[Ian Richardson]].<ref name=rowell160/> The following season, however, proved controversial: the double bill of ''The Padlock'' and ''[[Miss in Her Teens]]'', to mark the bicentenary of [[David Garrick]]'s death, and a revival of ''[[What the Butler Saw (play)|What the Butler Saw]]'' were deemed by the Arts Council unsuitable for touring repertory.<ref name=rowell160/> An internal report by Prospect now questioned "whether Prospect can any longer satisfy the triple task of filling the Vic, of satisfying the [Arts Council] Director of Touring's requirements for product of a certain familiar sort, and of realising the vision of Toby Robertson".<ref>Quoted in Rowell, p. 160</ref>
Robertson was in effect fired from the post of artistic director in 1980 while he was abroad with the company in China, Timothy West replacing him.<ref name=Guardian/> The following season, West's first as Robertson's successor, saw ''Macbeth'' with [[Peter O'Toole]], ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' with West as Shylock, and a gala performance presented to the Queen Mother to celebrate her eightieth birthday.<ref name=rowell161/> On 22 December 1980, four days after the gala performance, the Arts Council withdrew its funding from the Company, sealing its demise.<ref name=Continuum>{{cite book | last =Hunter | first =Adriana | authorlink = | title ="Prospect Theatre Company" in Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre | publisher =A&C Black | series = | volume =| edition = | date =2006 | location =| pages =623 | language = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=cFlFhuVMFGQC&pg=PA623&lpg=PA623&dq=%22The+Old+Vic%22+%22Prospect+Theatre%22+%22Toby+Robertson%22&source=bl&ots=mV8ooYukE5&sig=glE3lOsUU5ecrBRdq_ryN_aoDJA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qeYIVKGqJMzYao2MgvgJ&ved=0CCMQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Old%20Vic%22%20%22Prospect%20Theatre%22%20%22Toby%20Robertson%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =9781847140012 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref><ref name=rowell161>Rowell, p. 161</ref> In January the company left for its pre-arranged tour of Hong Kong and Australia. Appeals to the Council for funding to be reinstated were denied. The company gave a final season at the Old Vic staging ''The Merchant of Venice'', then gave a final tour of Europe, giving its last performance in Rome on 14 June before disbanding.<ref name=rowell161/>

{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=December 2012}} {{unreliable sources|date=December 2012}} }} [[File:Save Outdoor Sculpture! (logo).jpg|thumb|222px|right|The SOS! Logo]]
'''Save Outdoor Sculpture! (SOS!)''' is a community-based effort to identify, document, and conserve outdoor sculpture in the [[United States of America|United States]]. By fostering awareness and appreciation, SOS! aims to advocate proper care of a nationwide public resource.
The SOS! project may be viewed as a precursor of community-generated or "crowd-sourced" social media-driven initiatives.
==History== Save Outdoor Sculpture! was initiated by [[Heritage Preservation|Heritage Preservation: The National Institute of Conservation]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/conservation/publications/newsletters/22_2/news_in_cons1.html|title=Save Outdoor Sculpture!: A Community-Based Conservation Program, Getty Conservation Institute Newsletter 22.2 (Summer 2007)|accessdate=2009-12-10}}</ref> Thus far over 7,000 volunteers have cataloged and assessed the condition of over 30,000 publicly accessible statues and monuments installed outside.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritagepreservation.org/Programs/Sos/aboutsos.htm|title=Save Outdoor Sculpture! About Page|accessdate=2009-04-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108041805/http://www.heritagepreservation.org/Programs/SOS/aboutsos.htm|archivedate=2009-01-08|df=}}</ref>
The Smithsonian Museum of American Art has become an active partner in the SOS! project, and SOS! material is available online as part of the Inventory of American Sculpture at the Smithsonian American Art Museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siris.si.edu/|title=The Inventory is part of the Smithsonian Institution Research Information System|accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref> This partnership has allowed the database that contains these records to be viewable online, and [http://sirismm.si.edu/siris/ariquickstart.htm searchable by state], [http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1HD764961858K.5006&profile=ariall&menu=search&submenu=Browse&ts=1337649618636 artist, subject or title]. The records in the Inventory pertain to all sculpture in the United States and a few outlying islands that have thus far been identified.
==Educational programs== A primary objective of SOS! is to educate, and a number of programs have been created for children. For example, SOS! has partnered with the [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] to create a Girl Scout patch<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritagepreservation.org/PDFS/gsupdate.pdf|title=Save Outdoor Sculpture! Girl Scout Patch Program|accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref> for scouts who participate in the project.
